entry.field: Country / Countries where the Buddhadharma has spread, Buddhist countries
Nowadays, there are more and more countries where the buddhadharma has spread/is spreading, right?
ནང་ཆོས། = Buddhism; དར་བ། = to spread, to become widespread, as in: རྒྱལ་དར། = national flag, དར་ལྕོག = prayer flags; ས། = place, earth, as in: ལྷ་ས། Lhasa; ལུང་པ། = country, valley
Sir, Mr., Master, Venerable, Your Honour
Dear Sir, good morning! (H) May I ask you a few questions regarding Buddhism? (H) (h)
སྐུ། = body, as in: སྐུ་གཟུགས་བདེ་པོ་ཡིན་པས། How are you? (H), སྐུ་འདྲ། = statue; ཞབས། (H) = རྐང་པ། = leg, foot, as in: ཞབས་ཞུ་བ། = waiter, servant, སྨན་ཞབས། = nurse
Questions regarding the Dharma, Dharma-related questions (H)
If you ask me, among all questions, the dharma-related ones are the most interesting. (H)

ནང་ཆོས། = Buddhism; འབྲེལ་བ། = connection, relation, as in: འབྲེལ་སྒྲ། = connective particle; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ་, བཀའ་འདྲི། (H) = དྲི་བ། = question; བཀའ། = speech, as in: བཀའ་དང་བསྟན་བཅོས། = (the Buddha’s) words (sūtras) and commentaries (śāstras)
Different types, kinds, groups of religious traditions
I’m very pleased that the city where I live has temples from different religious traditions.

ཆོས་ལུགས། = religious tradition, religion, as in: ནང་ཆོས། = Buddhism, ལུགས་སྲོལ། = tradition, custom; ཁག = batch, group; མི། = དགག་སྒྲ། = negation particle; འདྲ་བ། = to be similar, the same, as in: སྐུ་འདྲ། = statue
Opinion, point of view, way of thinking (H)
In my Lama’s opinion, it is of utmost importance to be highly respectful towards elderly people.
དགོངས་པ། (H) = བསམ་པ། = to think; ཚུལ། = way, manner, as in: གནས་ཚུལ། = situation, way of abiding
Since the objective(s) of today's meeting is/are crystal clear, I think it will be very beneficial.
དམིགས་པ། = to focus, as in: དམིགས་རྟེན། support upon which to focus; ཡུལ། = object, place, as in: བལ་ཡུལ། = Nepal, འབྲུག་ཡུལ། = Bhutan, ཡུལ་ལྗོངས། = landscape, scenery
The benefit and welfare of sentient beings
There are various beings in this world who work for the benefit of sentient beings. Some are holy Lamas and Rinpoches, some are lay people, and some are even ordinary, humble people.

སེམས་ཅན། = living being, sentient being; སེམས་ as in: སེམས་ཙམ་པ། = Yogācāra, Perception Only; ཕན་བདེ། = ཕན་པ་དང་བདེ་བ།, benefit and welfare, ཕན། as in: ཕན་ཐོགས་ཆེན་པོ། = beneficial; བདེ་ as in: ཞི་བདེ། = peace and happiness, well-being
Because the people listening to the dharma had various motivations and dispositions, the Buddha, the Transcendent Conqueror turned the wheel of the dharma three times.
བསམ་པ། = thought, as in: བསམ་བློ་གཏོང་བ། = to think, to reflect; མོས་པ། = dedication, as in: རེ་མོས་བྱས་ནས། = alternately
Place (from) where it spread(s), originated, disseminated
Did you know that Buddhism didn't originate in Tibet? Of course! Buddhism only spread to Tibet around the 7th century.

དར་བ། = to spread, to be spread, as in: རྒྱལ་དར། = national flag, དར་ལྕོག = prayer flags; ས། = place, earth, as in: ས་ཆུ་མེ་རླུང་ནམ་མཁའ། = earth, water, fire, air and space, ལྷ་ས། = Lhasa, place of the god(s)
The noble/holy land of India, land of the noble
Because Buddhism first spread from India, Tibetans also consider the Noble Land of India sacred.
རྒྱ་ཆེན་པོ། = vast, broad; རྒྱ་ as in: རྒྱ་མཚོ། = ocean, vast lake, རྒྱ་གར། = India, རྒྱ་ནག = China; དར་བ། = to spread, to be spread, as in: རྒྱལ་དར། = national flag, དར་ལྕོག = prayer flags
The reason(s) why it should be called “x”
What is the reason for calling them the “early and late transmission of the dharma”? Because Buddhism spread in Tibet in two stages.

ཟེར་བ། = to be called, as in: ཟེར་སྲོལ། = traditional way of saying; དགོས་པ། = need to, must; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།, རྒྱུ་མཚན། = reason; རྒྱ་ as in: ལས་རྒྱུ་འབྲས། = karma, cause and effect; མཚན་ as in: མཚན་ཉིད། = characteristic, definition
Holy beings, wise beings, sublime beings, wise person
In your opinion, are there still wise, sublime beings in today's society like in the past?
སྐྱེས་པ། = to be born, as in: སྐྱེས་དམན། = woman, lower rebirth; བུ། = son; དམ་པ། = holy, sacred, as in: དམ་པའི་ཆོས། = the holy, sacred Dharma
Although that old siddha has all kinds of miraculous powers, he is very humble.
གྲུབ་པ། = accomplished, achieved, as in: ཚིག་གྲུབ། = sentence; ཐོབ་པ། = to gain, to obtain, as in: ཐོབ་ཐང་། = right, privilege
Have you ever read the biography of Buddha Shakyamuni, Old Path - White Clouds? Yes, I’ve read it in both Tibetan and English. (H)
སངས་རྒྱས། = Buddha, སངས། = to have purified, རྒྱས། = to have increased, expanded; ཤཱཀྱ། = Śākya; ཐུབ་པ། = the Mighty One
That which the Buddha spoke is called 'the Teaching' because it showed the path to liberation. (H)
བསྟན་པ། = the teaching, as in: བསྟན་པ། = to have shown, taught, taken out
There is a majestic white dragon on the Bhutanese national flag.
འབྲུག = dragon, as in: འབྲུག་སྐད་རྒྱག་པ། = to thunder; ཡུལ། = place, object, as in: དམིགས་ཡུལ། = object of focus, བལ་ཡུལ། = Nepal
Some years ago I saw a good movie made in Mongolia. It’s called “the crying camel”.
སོག = a clan, straw; ཡུལ། = place, object, as in: དམིགས་ཡུལ། = object of focus, བལ་ཡུལ། = Nepal
From many hiking places in Nepal one can take amazingly beautiful pictures of the Himalayan range, right?
ཧི་མ་ལ་ཡ། = Himalaya; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; རི། = mountain, as in: གངས་རི། = snow mountain; རྒྱུད། as in: རྒྱུད་བླ་མ། = The Sublime Continuum, Uttaratantraśāstra
What does the red circle in the Japanese national flag illustrate? It shows the sun.
ཉི། as in: ཉི་མ། = sun, as in: གཟའ་ཉི་མ། = Sunday
Before Buddhism spread to Tibet, it had already spread to many other Asian countries.

ཤར་གླིང་། = Asia; ཤར། = East, as in: ཤར་ལྷོ་ནུབ་བྱང་། = East, South, West, North, ཉི་མ་ཤར་བ། = sunrise; གླིང་ as in: གླིང་ག = park, མཚོ་གླིང་། = island; གི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; ལུང་པ། = country, as in: དབྱིན་ཇིའི་ལུང་པ།
Was the famous and skilled author Henry David Thoreau born in the 20th century? (H) No, in the 19th century.
དུས་རབས། = century; དུས། as in: དུས་ཚོད། = time, དུས་འཁོར་དབང་ཆེན། = Kālacakra initiation; རབས་ as in: མི་རབས། = generation, ཡ་རབས་སྤྱོད་བཟང་། = excellent noble behavior; ཉི་ཤུ་པ། = twentieth
The West, (lit. the western side, direction)
In some people’s opinion, one should not use the term “the West”.
ནུབ། = west, as in: ནུབ་པ། = to go down (sun); ཕྱོགས། = direction, as in: ཕྱོགས་རིས། = partiality
When did Buddhism first spread to Tibet? It started in the 7th century. We call that “the early transmission”.
སྔ། as in: སྔ་པོ། = early; དར་བ། = to spread
When was the “later transmission”? Between the 10th and 12th century.
The Buddha's spoken teachings are called "Sutras". (H)
མདོ། = sūtra, discourse of the Buddha
In their home, three generations - the grandfather and grandmother, their son and four grandchildren - live together harmoniously.
Thonmi Sambhota studied Sanskrit in the noble land of India. (H)
ལེགས། = good, positive; སྦྱར་བ། = to join together, to prepare, as in སྦྱོར་ལམ། = Path of Joining or Path of Preparation; སྐད། = language, as in བོད་སྐད། = Tibetan language
Because the Sutras of the Buddha were quite difficult to read, the learned masters composed many commentaries. (H)
བསྟན་པ། = past of to show, teach; བཅོས་པ། = to fabricate, alter, etc. as in བཟོ་བཅོས་རྒྱག་པ། = to fix, repair
Acharya, master, spiritual teacher, learned scholar
Master Asanga is considered the disciple of the Protector Maitreya.
སློབ་པ། = to teach, as in སློབ་གྲྭ། = school; དཔོན་ as in དཔོན་པ། = boss, or ཚོང་དཔོན། = seller, business man
Tripitaka, the three baskets, three collections of scriptures, three scriptural collections
What are the three baskets? The Vinaya (monastic code), the Sutras (word of the Buddha) and the Abhidharma.
སྡེ། = section, as in སྡེ་ཚན། = group, unit, division; སྣོད། = vessel; གསུམ། = three
A commentary is generally understood to be that which explains the intent of the Buddha spoken in the Sutra. (H)
དགོངས་པ། = intent, thought, (H) as in དགོངས་ཚུལ། = opinion or དགོངས་དག = sorry, lit. pure thought; འགྲེལ། = explanation, as in འགྲེལ་བཤད་རྒྱག་པ།
To accomplish, to achieve, to prove, to affirm (ཐ་དད་པ།)
If one puts the expression “to accomplish the benefit and happiness of others” into everyday language, it probably means to help and support people and animals.
To be respectful, to have/show respect, to have reverence (ཐ་དད་པ།)
Wherever one goes in the world, being respectful is always considered excellent behavior, right?

གུས། = respect; ཞབས། (H) = foot, leg, as in: ཞབས་ཞུ་བ། = waiter, སྨན་ཞབས་པ། = nurse; བྱེད་པ། = to do, verbalizer also used with many other nouns such as ཡིད་ཆེས་བྱེད་པ། = to trust, ལས་ཀ་བྱེད་པ། = to work
To come, to arrive, to reach (ཐ་མི་དད་པ།)
According to him, in some dialects, they say “to arrive” instead of “to come”. (H)
To spread, expand, extend widely, vastly (ཐ་མི་དད་པ།)
Even though Buddhism spread widely during the time of the Buddha, afterwards, it declined.
རྒྱ་ཆེན་པོ། = vast, broad; རྒྱ་ as in: རྒྱ་མཚོ། = ocean, vast lake, རྒྱ་གར། = India, རྒྱ་ནག = China; དར་བ། = to spread, to be spread, as in: རྒྱལ་དར། = national flag, དར་ལྕོག = prayer flags
Decrease, decline, degenerate, diminish the teaching (ཐ་མི་དད་པ།)
One of the main reasons why Buddhism diminished in Tibet was king Langdarma, right?

བསྟན་པ། = the teaching, as in: བསྟན་འཛིན། = holder of the teaching, བསྟན་བཅོས། = commentary, treatise; ཉམས་པ། = to degenerate, decline; ཉམས་ as in: ཉམས་ལེན་བྱེད་པ། = to practice, ཉམས་མྱོང་། = experience
To start, to begin, to initiate (ཐ་དད་པ།)
Many people consider Thonmi Sambhota as the one who started literacy in Tibet.
To reply, answer, give an answer (H) (honorific of ལན་རྒྱག་པ།) (ཐ་དད་པ།)
Whenever we ask our Lama a question, she always replies with a pure intention. (h) (H)
ལན། = answer, as in: དྲི་བ་དྲི་ལན། = dialogue; སྐྱོན་པ། (H) = རྒྱག་པ། = to do, verbalizer used with many nouns such as སྒོ་རྒྱག་པ། = to close the door, སྐད་རྒྱག་པ། = to shout
If he gets a chance to visit Samye monastery next year, he will probably go immediately. (H)
གོ་སྐབས། = chance, opportunity, as in: སྐབས་སྐབས་ལ། = sometimes; རག་པ། = to get, receive
The main reason for introducing Tibetan literacy was to translate the Sutras and Commentaries into Tibetan language.
བོད་ཡིག = Literary Tibetan; གསར། = new, as in ལོ་གསར། = new Year; དུ། = ལ་དོན།; རྩོམ་པ། = to compose, as in རྩོམ་པ་པོ། = author
To invite, to call to come (H) (h) (ཐ་དད་པ།)
The dharma king Trisong Detsen invited many masters to Tibet, such as Shantarakshita and Kamalashila, etc.. (H) (h)
གདན། = seat, cushion, throne, residence; འདྲེན་པ། = guide, lead, draw; ཞུ་བ། = to request, say (h)
The first and main site where the Buddhist scriptures were translated into Tibetan was Samye monastery.
བོད་ཡིག = written Tibetan; ལ། = ལ་དོན།; སྒྱུར་བ། = to change, transform
Because king Songtsen Gampo, king Drisong Detsen and king Ralpachen propagated the dharma, they are called the three dharma kings. (h)
ཆོས། = Dharma, doctrine, as in ནང་ཆོས། = Buddhism; སྤེལ་བ། = to increase, propagate
To cause to decline, to destroy (ཐ་དད་པ།)
There was also a king in Tibet who destroyed the dharma. His name was Langdarma. (H)
A Lama who was faithful to the dharma took the king Langdarma’s life, shooting him with an arrow.
It is a sad situation that many people must flee their countries due to war.
What is his main job/work these days? He does research on Tibetan history.
གཙོ་བོ། = main, as in: གཙོ་སེམས། = main mind
Various, different, of all kinds, manifold
It’s fun to gather with many people, because one gets to listen to different opinions and conversations. (H)
མི། = དགག་སྒྲ། = negation particle, འདྲ་བ། = to be similar, to be like, as in: སྐུ་འདྲ། = statue
(The religious tradition) which suits one's mindset, which one feels drawn to, comfortable with
If you find a religious tradition and Lama that suits your mindset, you are lucky.
སོ་སོ། = one's own, individual, as in: སོ་སོ་སྐྱེ་བོ། = ordinary being; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ་; བློ། = mind, as in: བློ་བཟང་། = kind hearted, kind minded; འབབ་པ། = to fall, as in: འབབ་ཆུ། = waterfall
As well as one can, to the best of one’s ability, as far as possible
Please do not worry, I’ll help you as much as I can. (H) (h)
གང་། = what; ཐུབ་པ། = to be able to
First, from the beginning, in the beginning
The stories about how the dharma first spread to Tibet are very interesting and amazing, aren’t they?
ཐོག = upper, utmost, roof, as in: ཐོག་བརྩེགས། = floor, storey of a building; ར། = ལ་དོན།
That time, at that time, at that moment
At that time, there was only the Shang Shung script, but not the script we have now, right?
དེ། = that, དེ་སྒྲ།, དུས། = time, as in: ནམ་དུས་བཞི། = the four seasons; དུས་ཚོད། = time; དུས་འཁོར་དབང་ཆེན། = Kālacakra initiation
Later, later on, in later times, after, afterwards
Later, due to the kindness of the three Dharma Kings, the dharma spread extensively.
ཕྱིས། = later, as in: ཕྱི་པོ་ཆགས་པ། = to get late, to be too late, སྐྱེ་བ་སྔ་ཕྱི། = past and future lives; སུ། = ལ་དོན།
I’m generally very interested in religious traditions. These days, I’ve developed a particular enthusiasm for Hinduism.
ལྷག་པ། = surpassing, exceeding, more, as in: ལྷག་བསམ། = supreme intent, ལྷག་པའི་བསླབ་པ་གསུམ། = the Three Excellent, Superior Trainings; དུ། = ལ་དོན།
From the depths of my heart, from the bottom of my heart (syn.: སེམས་ཀྱི་གཏིང་ནས་)
I’d like to thank you and express my gratitude from the depths of my heart for having explained a lot to me. (H) (h)

སྙིང་། = heart, as in: སྙིང་འདོད་པ། = to really want to do x, སྙིང་བསྡུས། = summary, compendium, outline; སྙིང་སྟོབས་ = courage; ཐག་པ། = root (also: rope, fetter); ནས། = from – འབྱུང་ཁུངས། source particle
In brief, in short, in a concise manner
It is extremely difficult to say something in brief about the way Buddhism spread to Tibet because there are so many interesting stories to tell.
མདོ། = sūtra; ར། = ལ་དོན།; བསྡུས་པ། = to be summarized, condensed; ནས། = འབྱུང་ཁུངས།
Why is the Buddha called a “teacher”? Because he shows the path to liberation, right?
སྟོན་པ། = to show, to teach, to extract [the meaning], as in: བསྟན་པ། = the teachings
Have you ever read the biography of Milarepa? - If you ask me, it’s very interesting.
རྣམ། = aspect, part; ཐར། = liberation, as in: ཚེ་ཐར་གཏོང་བ། = the practice of freeing animals who are about to be killed, as in: དྭགས་པོ་ཐར་རྒྱན། = The Jewel Ornament of Liberation
Although Tibet had some written language before Thonmi Sambhota, Tibetans regard him as the founder of their writing system.

སར། = new, as in: ཚིག་གསར། = vocabulary, new words, ལོ་གསར། = Tibetan New Year; གཏོད་པ། = to aim, to focus; མཛད་པ། = to do (H) as in: མཛད་སྒོ། = ceremony; མཁན། = nominaliser, showing the “doer” of an action
What is the name of Mingyur Rinpoche’s father? It’s Tulku Urgyen Rinpoche. (HH)
ཡབ། = father (HH), as in: ཡབ་ཡུམ། = parents (also refers to a deity with consort); ཀྱི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; མཚན། = name (H) as in: རྒྱུ་མཚན། = reason, མཚན་ཉིད། = characteristic, definition
In my opinion, the name of the Buddha’s mother is beautiful - it’s Maya Devi. (HH)
ཡུམ། = mother (HH), as in: ཡབ་ཡུམ། = parents (also refers to a deity with consort); གྱི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ། particle; མཚན། = name (H) as in: རྒྱུ་མཚན། = reason, མཚན་ཉིད། = characteristic, definition
Have you ever visited the Buddha’s birthplace? - Yes, I visited this sacred place last year. (H)

འཁྲུངས་པ། = to be born (H), as in: འཁྲུངས་སྐར་དུས་ཆེན། = festival of the birthday (of some important person); ས། = place, earth, as in: ས་ཆུ་མེ་རླུང་ནམ་མཁའ། = earth, water, fire, wind and space; ལྷ་ས། = the place of the god(s)
In which area of Tibet is Tashi Lhunpo monastery? If you ask me, I think it’s in the Central Tibetan area.

ས། = place, earth, as in: ས་ཆུ་མེ་རླུང་ནམ་མཁའ། = earth, water, fire, wind and space; ལྷ་ས། = Lhasa, the place of the god(s); ཕྱོགས། = direction, as in: ནུབ་ཕྱོགས། = the west, western direction, ཕྱོགས་རིས། = partiality
The Buddha’s birthplace is now in the south of Nepal. (HH) But when the Buddha was born there, there was no country called “Nepal”. (H)

བལ་ཡུལ། = Nepal; བལ། = wool; ཡུལ། = land, area; གྱི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; ལྷོ། = south, as in: ལྷོ་འཛམ་བུ་གླིང་། = the world; ཕྱོགས། = direction, as in: ནུབ་ཕྱོགས། = the west, western direction; ཕྱོགས་རིས། = partiality
How far is Lumbini from the Indian border? - Not far at all, it’s close.
རྒྱ་གར། = India; རྒྱ། = vast; གར། comes from: དཀར་པོ། = white; གྱི།= འབྲེལ་སྒྲ། particle; ས། = place; མཚམས། = border, as in: མཚམས་ལ་སྡོད་པ། = to stay in retreat
The level of Buddhahood, the state of Buddhahood
In my opinion, if one wants to obtain the level of Buddhahood, one probably has to practice a whole lot.

སངས་རྒྱས། = Buddha, སངས། = having purified, རྒྱས། = having developed, as in: ཡར་རྒྱས་འགྲོ་བ། = to get better, to improve; ཀྱི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; གོ་འཕང་། = level, state; གོ། = to hear, understand; འཕང་། = height
Since Tenzin-la’s grandmother is elderly, takes good care of her. (H) (h)
དགུང་ལོ། (H) = ལོ། = year, as in: ལོ་གསར། = New Year
Even though the facilities at the king’s residence were excellent, the Buddha was not happy living there. (H)

རྒྱལ་པོ། = king, as in: ཆོས་རྒྱལ་གསུམ། = the Three Dharma Kings (or Skt. dharmarājas), རྒྱལ་ས། = capital, ང་རྒྱལ། = pride; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ་; ཁབ། = residence, palace (also: needle, as in: རྒྱལ་ཁབ། = nation, ཁབ་རྒྱག་པ། = to give an injection
The five common, ordinary, general, traditional sciences
When the Buddha was young, he had the chance to study the five common sciences. (H)

ཐུན་མོང་། = common, ordinary; གི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; རིག་གནས། = science; རིག = knowledge, intelligence, as in: རིག་པ་སྤྱང་པོ། = clever, intelligent; གནས། = to abide, as in: གནས་སྟངས། = situation, ཞི་གནས། = calm abiding; ལྔ། = five, as in: ཚེས་པ་བཅོ་ལྔ། = the 15th day of the Tibetan lunar month
Art, skill, ability of body and mind
Are you interested in the arts? - Of course, I often go to museums to look at the paintings.
སྒྱུ། = deception, illusion, magical display; རྩལ། = skill, capacity, as in: ལུས་རྩལ། = sports, exercise, ལག་རྩལ། = handicraft
Since our professor does research about the philosophical tenets of the “outsider” schools, I’ve also become a bit excited about them. (H)

ཕྱི་རོལ་པ། = outsider, non Buddhist; ཕྱི། = outside, as in: ཕྱི་ལོགས་ལ། = outside, ཕྱི་རྒྱལ། = abroad, foreign country; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; གྲུབ་མཐའ། = philosophical tenet; གྲུབ་པ། = to be established, as in: དོན་གྲུབ། = one who has accomplished one's goal; མཐའ། = end, extreme, as in: མཐའ་ལ་མ་ལྷུང་བ། = not falling into extremes, མཐའ་མ་ལ། = in the end
Did you know that they hold a large Nyingma Prayer Festival in Bodhgaya every winter? - Of course, I’ve been twice. (h)
རྡོ་རྗེ། =vajra, as in: རྡོ་རྗེ་ཐེག་པ། = Vajrayāna; གདན། = seat, as in: ས་གདན། = floor rug
Deer park, forest of wild animals
I love the fact that the place the Buddha first taught was not a temple but a deer park. (H)
རི་དྭགས། = wild animals with hooves; ཀྱི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; ནགས། = forest, as in: ཤིང་ནགས། = forest, jungle, ནགས་ཚལ། = forest, jungle
Retinue of the five excellent disciples
The ones who first listened to what the Buddha said at the deerpark are known as “the retinue of the five excellent disciples”. (H)

འཁོར། = retinue, as in: འཁོར་ལོ། = wheel, དུས་འཁོར་དབང་ཆེན། = Kālacakra initiation; ལྔ། = five, as in: ཚེས་པ་བཅོ་ལྔ། = the 15th day of the Tibetan (lunar) month, full moon; སྡེ། = set, school, faction, as in: མདོ་སྡེ། = sūtra, set of teachings; བཟང་པོ། = kind, positive, as in: བློ་བཟང་། = kind minded, སེམས་པ་བཟང་པོ། = kind hearted
The three turnings of the wheel of dharma
There are debates about which of the three turnings of the wheel of the dharma are of provisional or definitive meaning.

ཆོས། = Dharma – comes from: འཆོས་པ། = to make, to repair, as in: ཆོས་ལུགས། = religious tradition; ཀྱི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ་; འཁོར་ལོ། = wheel, as in: རླུང་འཁོར། = fan, ventilator; རིམ་པ། = stages, as in: སྒོམ་རིམ། = The Stages of Meditation (by Kamalaśīla), ལམ་རིམ། = Stages of the Path (by Tsongkapa); གསུམ། = three, as in: དཀོན་མཆོག་གསུམ། = The Three Jewels
The first turning of the wheel of dharma, the first set of teachings
What did the Buddha teach during the first turning of the wheel of the dharma? About the Four Noble Truths. (H)
འཁོར་ལོ། = wheel, as in: རླུང་འཁོར། = fan, ventilator; དང་པོ། = first, as in: ལས་དང་པོ་བ། = beginner
Transcendent Conqueror, Transcendent Victor, Blessed One
Same people also call Buddha Shakyamuni “the Transcendent Conqueror”. (h)

བཅོམ་པ། = to conquer, to defeat; ལྡན། = to have, to be endowed with, as in: དགའ་ལྡན། = Gaden, the Tuṣita pure land; འདས་པ། = to have transcended, passed beyond, as in: མྱ་ངན་ལས་འདས་པ། = nirvāṇa, དུས་འདས་པ། = Past tense
Dharma of the Greater and Lesser Vehicles
It’s amazing that the Buddha taught a large variety of dharma of the Greater and Lesser Vehicle for the benefit of sentient beings. (H)

ཐེག་པ། = vehicle, carriage; ཆེ། = ཆེན་པོ། = big, large, as in: གླང་ཆེན། = elephant; ཆུང་། = small, as in: ཉམ་ཆུང་། = humble, modest; གི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; ཆོས། = Dharma, religious doctrine, religion as in: ཁ་ཆེའི་ཆོས་ལུགས། = Islam
Lama Zopa Rinpoche planned to build a statue of the Protector Maitreya in Kushinagar. (H)
རྩྭ། = grass, herb, as in: རྩྭ་སྨན། = herbal medicine; མཆོག = supreme, exalted, as in: དཀོན་མཆོག་གསུམ། = The Three Jewels; གྲོང་། = village, city, as in: གྲོང་གསེབ། = village, གྲོང་ཁྱེར། = city
Liberation, emancipation, freedom, freedom from the lower realms
The Buddha showing us the path to liberation isn't enough. We each must practice it ourselves. (H)
Do you think the second turning of the wheel of the dharma is provisional or definitive meaning? - No clue! I’m not clairvoyant.

དྲང་། = (1) straight, sincere, honest, as in དྲང་པོ་དྲང་རྐྱང་། = completely honest, (2) to lead (f. of འདྲེན་) one on or point the way; དོན། = meaning, like དོན་དག; དང་། = དང་སྒྲ།; ངེས་ = definitive, as in ངེས་པར་དུ། = definitely
I'll ask Rinpoche if “reaching enlightenment” and “becoming a Buddha” both mean the same thing. (H) (h)
བྱང་། = perfected, cleared, purified; ཆུབ། = comprehend, understand
My favorite religious book is the text “Entering the bodhisattva’s way of life” written by the great Son of the Victorious One, Shantideva.
བྱང་། = perfected, cleared, purified; ཆུབ། = comprehend, understand; སེམས། = mind, heart; དཔའ། = དཔའ་བོ། = hero, དཔའ་མོ། = heroine
If one talks about the biography of the Buddha in terms of the Twelve Auspicious Deeds, one will be able to tell it in detail.
མཛད་པ། = to do (H), act, deed; བཅུ་གཉིས། = twelve
If we talk about holy beings, it is good to use the most honorific term, like “to be born”, etc. (HH)
སྐུ། = body, as in: སྐུ་གཟུགས། = body (H), སྐུ་ཞབས། = Venerable (H), སྐུ་འདྲ། = statue; ལྟམ་པ། = to be born, to be full; ནས། = འབྱུང་ཁུངས། = after
What is the colloquial equivalent of “to be given a name”? It refers to naming somebody.
མཚན། = name (H) as in: རྒྱུ་མཚན། = reason, མཚན་ཉིད། = characteristic, definition; ལ། = ལ་དོན། particle; གསོལ་བ། = to ask, to request, to beg, as in: གསོལ་བ་འདེབས་པ། = to supplicate, to make a request
To achieve, to reach, to obtain, ཁ་སྐད།: to win (ཐ་མི་དད་པ།)
After having meditated under the Bodhi tree for the whole night, the Buddha achieved Buddhahood. (H)
To renounce, to become a monastic, to embrace a religious life (ཐ་དད་པ།)
Do you think wanting to practice the dharma definitely requires becoming a monastic?
རབ། = best, supreme, as in: ཡ་རབ། = polite, ཤེས་རབ། = insight; ཏུ། = ལ་དོན།; འབྱུང་བ། = to arise, to come about, as in: འབྱུང་ཁུངས། = source particle, འབྱུང་བ་ལྔ། = the five elements
To practice, accomplish the sacred dharma (ཐ་དད་པ།)
My Lama advised me that if I want to practice the dharma, I first need to listen to a lot of dharma talks. (H)
དམ་པ། = sacred, holy; ཆོས། = Dharma – comes from: འཆོས་པ། = to make, to correct, as in: ཧིན་དྷུའི་ཆོས། = Hinduism; སྒྲུབ། = to accomplish, as in: ཚིག་སྒྲུབ། = sentence
To reach enlightenment, to become a Buddha (ཐ་མི་དད་པ།)
Since the place where Buddha Shakyamuni reached enlightenment was under a tree, I consider all trees sacred.
སངས། = to have purified, རྒྱས། = to have unfolded, expanded, as in: ཡར་རྒྱས་གཏོང་བ། = to improve
Sometimes there are special signs when holy beings pass away, such as rainbows rising or snow in low areas, etc

དགོངས་པ། (H) = བསམ་པ། = thought, intent, as in: དགོངས་ཚུལ། (H) = opinion, point of view; རྫོགས་པ། = to be finished, to be completed, exhausted, as in: རྫོགས་ཆེན། = the Great Perfection, རྫོགས་རིམ། = Completion Stage
To pass into nirvana, to pass beyond sorrow, to transcend suffering (HH) (ཐ་མི་དད་པ།)
When Buddha Shakyamuni passed into nirvana in Kushinagar, he was elderly. (HH)
མྱ་ངན། = suffering, sorrow; ལས། = from (འབྱུང་ཁུངས། particle); འདས་པ། = to have gone beyond, to have transcended, as in: བཅོམ་ལྡན་འདས། = The Transcendent Conqueror, དུས་འདས་པ། = the Past tense
What is the meaning of “common”? It is kind of the opposite of “special”.
Wearing the turquoise to protect one’s spiritual life force might be a special tradition among Himalayan people.
The “three-year retreat” lasts a bit longer than three years and three months, right?

ལྷག = special, surpassing, exceeding, as in: ལྷག་བསམ། = supreme intent, ལྷག་པའི་བསླབ་པ་གསུམ། = the three superior trainings; ཙམ། = about, approximately, merely, as in: བདེ་པོ་ཨོ་ཙམ། = not too bad, སེམས་ཙམ་པ། = the adherent of the Perception Only School/Yogācārin
Based on your kindness, I have learned a little bit about the Bodhisattva (of great Compassion) Avalokiteshvara. Thank you! (H)
ཙམ། = approximately, merely, as in: བདེ་པོ་ཨོ་ཙམ། = not too bad, སེམས་ཙམ་པ། = Perception Only/Yogācārin, མིང་ཙམ། = mere name
The three Wheels of the Dharma, the Three Sets of teachings
I think the reason why the Buddha delivered the Three Sets of teachings is very profound.

ཆོས། = Dharma, doctrine, as in: ཡི་ཤུའི་ཆོས་ལུགས། = Christianity; ཀྱི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; འཁོར་ལོ། = wheel, as in: དུས་འཁོར་དབང་ཆེན། = Kālacakra initiation, རླུང་འཁོར། = fan, ventilator; རིམ་པ། = stages, as in: སྒོམ་རིམ། = Stages of Meditation (by Kamalaśīla), ལམ་རིམ། = Stages of the Path (by Tsongkapa); གསུམ། = three, as in: དཀོན་མཆོག་གསུམ། = The Three Jewels
As the topic of the (Three) Turnings of the Wheel is very interesting, please give a detailed explanation!
རྒྱས། = to have increased, as in: སངས་རྒྱས། = Buddha; བཤད་པ། = to say, to converse, as in: སྐད་ཆ་བཤད་པ། = to have a conversation
The first [set of] teachings, the First [Turning of the] Wheel of Dharma
Where did the First Turning of the wheel take place? It was in the Deer Park in Varanasi.
ཆོས། = Dharma, as in: ཆོས་ལུགས། = religious tradition; འཁོར། = wheel, as in: དུས་འཁོར་དབང་ཆེན། = Kālacakra initiation; དང་པོ། = first, as in: ལས་དང་པོ་བ། = beginner
The teaching/Turning of the Wheel of Dharma regarding the Four [Noble] Truths
What is the name of the First Turning of the wheel? It is the Dharma of the Four [Noble] Truths.

བདེན་པ། = Truth, as in: དྲང་བདེན། = honesty sincerity; བཞི། = four, as in: ནམ་དུས་བཞི། = the four seasons; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; ཆོས། = Dharma, as in: ཆོས་ལུགས། = religious tradition; འཁོར། = wheel, as in: དུས་འཁོར་དབང་ཆེན། = Kālacakra initiation
The Second Turning of the Wheel is called “the Middle Turning of the Wheel” because it was taught between the first and the last. (h)
བཀའ། = speech, as in: བཀའ་དང་བསྟན་བཅོས། = The Word of the Buddha and the Commentaries, བཀའ་མོལ་གནང་བ། = to have a conversation (H); བར་བ། = between, as in: བར་དུ། = until
[The turning of] the Wheel of Dharma [which taught] the absence of characteristics
If you ask me, the topic of the [the turning of] the Wheel of Dharma [which taught] the absence of characteristics is very tough and confusing.

མཚན་ཉིད། = characteristic, definition; མཚན། = name, mark; ཉིད། = emphasiser, as in: སྟོང་པ་ཉིད། = emptiness; མེད་པ། = not having, as in: ཤ་མེད། = vegetarian, བདག་མེད། = selflessness; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; ཆོས། = Dharma, as in: ཆོས་ལུགས། = religious tradition; འཁོར། = wheel, as in: དུས་འཁོར་དབང་ཆེན། = Kālacakra initiation, རྐང་འཁོར། = bicycle
Among the Three Turnings of the Wheel of the Dharma, my favorite is the third set of teachings because it's about buddha nature.

བཀའ། = speech, as in: བཀའ་དང་བསྟན་བཅོས། = The Word of the Buddha and the commentaries, བཀའ་མོལ་གནང་བ། = to have a conversation (H); མཐའ་མ། = last, final, end, as in: གྲུབ་མཐའ། = philosophical tenet, མཐའ་ལ་མ་ལྷུང་བ། = not falling into extremes
The Wheel of Dharma of correct/thorough differentiation
The name of the Third Turning of the Wheel is long. It is called “the Wheel of Dharma of correct/thorough differentiation”, right? (h)

ལེགས། = good, excellent, as in: བཀྲ་ཤིས་བདེ་ལེགས། = 'hello!'; རྣམ་པ། = parts, aspects; ཕྱེ་བ། = to discern, to distinguish, as in: དབྱེ་བ་ཕྱེ་བ། = to differentiate; ཆོས། = Dharma, as in: ཆོས་ལུགས། = religious tradition; འཁོར། = wheel, as in: དུས་འཁོར་དབང་ཆེན། = Kālacakra initiation
What’s the topic of today’s Dharma talk? Our lama said she will speak about Milarepa’s hagiography. (H)
བརྗོད་པ། = to express, as in: བརྗོད་ཡུལ་ལས་འདས་པ། = inexpressible, beyond words; བྱ། = must do, action, as in: བྱ་ཚིག = verb, བྱ་བ། = action
The Four Noble Truths, the Four Truths of the Noble Ones
In my opinion, while the Four Noble Truths may appear quite simple at first glance, they are actually quite profound.

འཕགས་པ། = Noble One, as in: རྒྱ་གར་འཕགས་པའི་ཡུལ། = the noble land of India; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; བདེན་པ། = truth, as in: དྲང་བདེན། = honesty, sincerity; བཞི། = four, as in: ནམ་དུས་བཞི། = the four seasons
Of the Four Noble Truths taught by the Buddha, the Transcendent Conqueror, the first is the Truth of Suffering.
སྡུག་བསྔལ། = suffering; སྡུག as in: སྡུག་པོ། = bad, poor, miserable; བསྔལ། = pain; གྱི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; བདེན་པ། = truth, as in: དྲང་བདེན། = honesty, sincerity
If one wants to give up suffering, one probably first needs to make sure one knows the Truth of Origin well, since this is its cause.

ཀུན། = all, as in: ཀུན་དགའ། = Ānanda, ཀུན་རྫོབ། = relative, conventional; འབྱུང་བ། = to arise, as in: འབྱུང་བ་ལྔ། = the five elements, འབྱུང་ཁུངས། = source particle; གི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; བདེན་པ། = truth, as in: དྲང་བདེན། = honesty, sincerity
When I first heard about the Truth of Cessation, I got excited because I began to trust that there is not only suffering but also happiness.
འགོག་པ། = to be stopped, to cease, as in: དགག་སྒྲ། = negation particle; བདེན་པ། = truth, as in: དྲང་བདེན། = honesty, sincerity
Since Buddha Śākyamuni taught us the Truth of the Path, we need not worry. If we practice it, there is freedom from suffering. (H)

ལམ། = path, as in: ལམ་ཀ = road, path, ལམ་ལྔ། = the Five Paths, ཚོགས་ལམ། = the Path of Accumulation, སྦྱོར་ལམ། = the Path of Joining; གྱི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; བདེན་པ། = truth, as in: དྲང་བདེན། = honesty, sincerity
Because [our] professor gave a clarification, all students felt relieved. (H)
གསལ། = གསལ་པོ། = clear, as in: དམིགས་བསལ། = especially; བཤད་པ། = to say, to express, as in: སྐད་ཆ་བཤད་པ། = to have a conversation
In the Buddhist scriptures it says that the nature of saṃsāra is suffering, right? Do you agree? (H)
འཁོར་བ། = saṃsāra, as in: འཁོར་ལོ། = wheel, རླུང་འཁོར། = fan, ventilator, དུས་འཁོར་དབང་ཆེན། = Kālacakra initiation
Did you know that Kushinagar is the place where the Buddha, the Transcendent Conqueror, passed into nirvāṇa? (H)
མྱ་ངན། = suffering, sorrow; ལས། = འབྱུང་ཁུངས། = from; འདས་པ། = to have transcended, as in: བཅོམ་ལྡན་འདས། = The Transcendent Conqueror, དུས་འདས་པ། = past tense
The cause(s) and result(s) of saṃsāra
Among the Four Noble Truths, the second and the first are about the cause(s) and result(s) of saṃsāra, right? Correct.

འཁོར་བ། = saṃsāra, as in: འཁོར་ལོ། = wheel, རླུང་འཁོར། = fan, ventilator, སྲིད་པ་ཁམས་གསུམ་འཁོར་བ། = the three realms of cyclic existence; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; རྒྱུ། = cause, as in: རྒྱུ་རྐྱེན། = causes and conditions, རྒྱུ་མཚན། = reason; དང་། = དང་སྒྲ། = and; འབྲས་བུ། = result, effect, as in: ལས་རྒྱུ་འབྲས། = karma, cause and effect, འབྲས། = rice
The cause(s) and result(s) of nirvāṇa
The Fourth and Third Noble Truths are about the cause(s) and result(s) of nirvāṇa,་right? Yes, exactly. (H)

མྱ་ངན། = suffering, sorrow; ལས། = འབྱུང་ཁུངས། = from; འདས་པ། = to have transcended, as in: བཅོམ་ལྡན་འདས། = The Transcendent Conqueror; དུས་འདས་པ་ = pPast tense; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; རྒྱུ། = cause, as in: རྒྱུ་རྐྱེན། = causes and conditions, རྒྱུ་མཚན། = reason; དང་། = དང་སྒྲ། = and; འབྲས་བུ། = result, effect, as in: ལས་རྒྱུ་འབྲས། = karma, cause and effect, འབྲས། = rice
What is to be given up, what needs to be abandoned, discarded
At the Dharma talk, our རིན་པོ་ཆེ། advised us that unwholesome behaviors such as being proud or jealous are to be abandoned. (H)
སྤང་བ། = to abandon, to discard; བྱ། = that which one must do, as in: བྱ་བ། = action, activity, བྱ་ཚིག = verb
What is to be practiced, what needs to be adopted, cultivated
When first practicing Dharma, it seems important to identify what should be adopted and what should not.

ཉམས་པ། = to degenerate, as in: ཉམས་ལེན་བྱེད་པ། = to practice; བླང་བ། = to adopt, to take up, as in: བླང་དོར་གྱི་གནས། = what is to be adopted and what is to be given up; བྱ། = that which one must do, as in: བྱ་བ། = action, activity, བྱ་ཚིག = verb
The term “prajñāpāramitā” refers to the perfection of wisdom, right? No clue, I don’t know. It might be best to ask your lama/spiritual teacher. (H) (h)
ཤེར་ཕྱིན། =Prajñāpāramitā; ཤེར། = ཤེས་རབ། = wisdom; ཕྱིན། = went, as in: ཕ་རོལ་ཏུ་ཕྱིན་པ། = pāramitā
If one speaks in terms of the Buddhist view, all phenomena are considered empty and lacking a self.
ཆོས། = dharma, phenomena; ཐམས་ཅད། = all, as in: སེམས་ཅན་ཐམས་ཅད། = all sentient beings
The verse “form is emptiness - emptiness is form” in the Heart Sūtra is famous, right?
སྟོང་པ། = empty, as in: གཟུགས་སྟོང་པའོ།། = “Form is empty”; ཉིད། = emphasizer, as in: མཚན་ཉིད། = definition, characteristic, རང་ཉིད་གཅིག་པུ། = I myself, alone
Last year, my friend had a chance to go to Vulture Peak on a pilgrimage with her Dharma friends.

བྱ། = bird, as in: བྱ་ཤ = chicken; རྒོད། = wild, as in: བྱིང་རྒོད། = dullness and agitation; ཕུང་པོ། = heap, skandha, as in: ཕུང་པོ་ལྔ། = the five aggregates; རི་བོ། = mountain, as in: གངས་རི། = snow mountain, རི་རབ། = Mount Meru
The bodhisattvas who were listening to the Buddha’s Dharma teaching are called the “retinue”.
འཁོར། = retinue, as in: འཁོར་ལོ། = wheel
The bodhisattva Kashyapa listened to the Dharma talk during the second turning of the Wheel.
འོད། = light, as in: འོད་ཟེར། = light ray; སྲུང་། = to guard, as in: སྲུང་སྐྱོབ་བྱེད་པ། = to protect
Along with Kashyapa, the Bodhisattva called Subhūti also climbed Vulture peak to listen to [the turning of] the Wheel of Dharma [which taught] the absence of characteristics.
རབ། = completely, as in: ཤེས་རབ། = wisdom; འབྱོར་ལྡན། = rich, as in: དལ་འབྱོར་བཅོ་བརྒྱད། = the eighteen freedoms and riches
There are many Buddhists who believe that Ānanda memorized all the sūtras spoken by the Buddha.
མདོ། = sūtra; སྡེ། = section, part, unit
The Saṃdhinirmocana Sūtra, The Sūtra that Unravels the Intent
The Buddha taught the Saṃdhinirmocana Sūtra in the context of the Third Turning of the Wheel, right?

དགོངས་པ། (H) = བསམ་པ། = thought, intent, as in: དགོངས་ཚུལ། (H) = opinion; ངེས། = certainty, as in: ངེས་ཤེས་སྒྲོན་མེ། = The Beacon of Certainty (by མི་ཕམ་རིན་པོ་ཆེ།); འགྲེལ། = to explain, as in: ࠠགྲེལ་བཤད་རྒྱག་པ། = to explain, elucidate
Laṅkāvatāra Sūtra, Ascent onto Lanka, Descent into Lanka Sūtra
I have heard that in the Laṅkāvatāra Sūtra, the Buddha spoke about the environment. But I don’t remember exactly.
ལང་ཀར། = Lanka; གཤེགས་པ། = to travel, to go, to come, as in: བདེ་གཤེགས་སྙིང་པོ། = buddha-nature
Do you think that animals such as bugs, snakes, crocodiles, etc. also have Buddha-Nature? Of course!

བདེ། = bliss, happiness, as in: ཞི་བདེ། = peace and happiness, བདེ་པོ། = fine, comfortable; གཤེགས་པ། = to travel, to go, to come; སྙིང་པོ། = essence, as in: སྙིང་། = heart, སྙིང་བསྡུས། = summary, སྙིང་རྗེ་པོ། = pretty, beautiful
Yesterday I got a bit confused at the Dharma talk because [he] spoke a lot about profound topics like the nature of mind, etc. (H)
སེམས། = mind, heart, as in: སེམས་པ་བཟང་པོ། = kind hearted; ཀྱི། = ࠠབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; རང་བཞིན། = nature; རང་། = self, as in: རང་སྦྱོང་། = self study
When I first heard about the nature of mind being luminosity, I didn’t believe it. But now, slowly but surely, I’m beginning to trust it.
འོད། = light, as in: ོࠠད་ཟེར། = rays of light; གསལ་བ། = clear, as in: དམིགས་བསལ། = especially གསལ་སྟོང་ཟུང་འཇུག = the unity of clarity and emptiness
Have you ever been to Vaiśālī? What are you talking about? I don’t even know where that sacred place is. (H)
ཡངས་པ། = wide, spacious; ཅན། = having, as in: སེམས་ཅན། = animal
The teacher asked which country Mount Malaya, the sacred place of the Third Turning of the Wheel, was in, but none of the students were able to respond. (H)
རི་བོ། = mountain, as in: གངས་རི། = snow mountain; མ་ལ་ཡ། = Malaya
When practicing the Dharma, the order is important. In many scriptures, the sequence is written like this: listening, reflection, meditation. (H)
གོ་རིམ། = order, རིམ། =stage, as in: སྒོམ་རིམ། = Stages of Meditation, ལམ་རིམ། = Stages of the Path
The word “text / government” has two different meanings: one relates to politics, one means “unbound scripture”.
གཞུང་། = text, as in: རིག་གཞུང་། = culture
The Madhyamika in Four Hundred Verses (Skt. Catuḥśataka)
Who is the author of Madhyamika in Four Hundred [Verses]? It is the ācārya “Noble Divinity”, in Sanskrit he is called Āryadeva. (h)
དབུ་མ། = Madhyamika, དབུ། = middle, as in: དབུ་མའི་ལམ། = the Middle way; བཞི་བརྒྱ། = 400
Self, atman, I, me, oneself, ego
The entire profound grammar of Colloquial Tibetan is pervaded by the principle of self and other.
བདག། = self, as in: བདག་གཞན། = self and other, བདག་མེད། = selflessness
The way to reverse, how to reverse
My dear Dharma friend བསྟན་འཕེལ་ལགས enjoys talking about the way to reverse unmeritorious actions. (H) (h)
བཟླག་པ།= to reverse; ཚུལ། = way, manner, as in: བསམ་ཚུལ། = opinion, way of thinking, གནས་ཚུལ། = situation
According to the Tibetan people’s worldview, it’s especially important to accumulate meritorious karma on special dates such as the full moon, etc.
བསོད་ནམས། = merit; ཀྱི། = ࠠབྲེལ་སྒྲ།, ལས། = karma, action, as in: ལས་ཀ = work, ལས་རྒྱུ་འབྲས། = karma, cause and effect
The way to accomplish, how to accomplish
After giving up the ten non-virtues, one probably needs to think about the way to accomplish virtuous actions, such as protecting lives and practicing generosity.
སྒྲུབ་པ། = to accomplish, as in: ཚིག་སྒྲུབ། = sentence; ཚུལ། = way, manner, as in: བསམ་ཚུལ། = opinion, way of thinking, གནས་ཚུལ། = situation
Clinging to a [concept of] self, ego clinging, self grasping
In the Buddhist scriptures, they consider clinging to a self as the cause of all afflictions, right?
བདག = self, as in: བདག་གཞན། = self and other, བདག་མེད། = selflessness; ࠠཛིན་པ། = to hold, grasp, as in: ࠠཛིན་གྲྭ། = class, བློ་ལ་འཛིན་པ། = to keep in mind, memorize
The way to stop, the manner of abandoning, how to discard
I think that it will be beneficial if she asks her lama about the way of giving up bad habits such as drinking alcohol. (H) (h)
སྤང་བ། = to abandon, to discard; ཚུལ། = way, manner, as in: བསམ་ཚུལ། = opinion, way of thinking, གནས་ཚུལ། = situation
In the unbound text I read yesterday, it says that there are two types of selflessness, the selflessness of the person and the selflessness of phenomena. (H)
བདག་ as in: བདག་འཛིན། = grasping to a self; མེད། = absence, non-existence
The way of realizing, how to realize
There is a lot written in the Buddhist scripture about the way of realizing selflessness. This topic is very vast and profound.
རྟོགས་པ། = to realize, as in: སྤང་རྟོགས་ཀྱི་ཡོན་ཏན། = the qualities of renunciation and realization
What is written in the Protector Nāgārjuna’s Letter to a Friend? It says that mindfulness is the basis of all good qualities. (H)
གཞི། = basis, as in: འཆར་གཞི། = plan
The union of clarity and emptiness
The nun said that she hopes and has the aspiration that if she meditates for many years and lifetimes, she will be able to realize the union of clarity and emptiness. (H)

གསལ། = clear, as in: དམིགས་བསལ། = especially; སྟོང་། = empty, as in: སྟོང་པ་ཉིད། = emptiness; ཟུང་འཇུག = union, unity; ཟུང་། = pair, side; འཇུག་པ། = to enter, engage, as in: རྟགས་ཀྱི་འཇུག་པ། = The Application of Genders, སྤྱོད་འཇུག = Bodhisattvacaryāvatāra
The way in which something is

My རྩ་བའི་བླ་མ། explains the way all phenomena are empty and devoid of a self in terms of the soil, the sky and the sunshine being the cause of the flower and that the flower is not established from its own essence. (H)
ཡིན། = to be; ཚུལ། = way, manner, as in: བསམ་ཚུལ། = opinion, གནས་ཚུལ། = situation
To turn the Wheel of the Dharma, give teachings
I wonder what was the reason that Buddha Śākyamuni had to turn the Wheel of the Dharma three times.

ཆོས། = Dharma, as in: ཡི་ཤུའི་ཆོས་ལུགས། = Christianity; ཀྱི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; འཁོར་ལོ། = wheel, as in: དུས་འཁོར་དབང་ཆེན། = Kālacakra initiation, རླུང་འཁོར། = fan, ventilator; བསྐོར་བ། = to turn, as in: སྐོར་ར་རྒྱག་པ། = to do circumambulations
To reverse, stop, overcome, oppose, turn back from
The venerable monk said that if one is unable to stop unmeritorious actions, there is probably no way out of saṃsāra. (H)
What is the major topic of the Dharma talk? Since it will be about the way of practicing གཏོང་ལེན། meditation, it will surely be interesting and beneficial.
གཙོ་བོ། = main, as in: གཙོ་སེམས། = main mind, དམངས་གཙོ། = democracy
Not established in terms of having their own essence
Does one really need to do a three-year retreat in order to realize that all phenomena are not established in terms of their own essence?
རང་། = oneself, as in: རང་སྦྱོང་། = self study; ངོ་བོ། = essence, as in: ངོ་བོ་ཉིད་ཀྱི་སྐུ་ = svabhāvikakāya; མ། = དགག་སྒྲ།; གྲུབ་པ། = to be established, as in: ཚིག་གྲུབ། = sentence
[They are] not established in terms of having/by means of their own characteristics
When some people first hear about how all phenomena are not established in terms of having their own characteristics, they consider this to be nihilism.

རང་། = oneself, as in: རང་སྦྱོང་། = self study; གི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ་; མཚན་ཉིད། = characteristic, definition; མཚན། name (H), mark; ཉིད། = emphasizer, as in: སྟོང་པ་ཉིད། = emptiness; ཀྱིས། = བྱེད་སྒྲ།; མ། = དགག་སྒྲ་, as in: མ་རིག་པ། = ignorance; གྲུབ་པ། = to be established, as in: ཚིག་གྲུབ། = sentence
According to you, are the two terms “non-meritorious” and “unvirtuous” identical?
བསོད་ནམས། = merit, མ། = not, as in: མ་རིག་པ། = ignorance
I wonder what the reason might be for calling ...
I wonder what the reason might be for calling the Third Turning the Wheel of Dharma of correct/thorough differentiation. (H)
ཞུ་བ། = to say (h), as in: ཞབས་ཞུ་བ། = waiter, servant; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; རྒྱུ་མཚན། = reason, རྒྱུ། = cause; མཚན། = name (H), mark; ག་རེ། = what?; ཡིན་ན། = I wonder
At the Dharma talk on Saturday, our བླ་མ། gave a beautiful explanation about how to give up the Three Flaws. (H)
སྐྱོན། = fault, flaw; གསུམ། = three, as in: དཀོན་མཆོག་གསུམ། = Tthe Three Jewels
the Four Perceptions, the Four Ways of Perceiving
Have you ever heard of the four perceptions? - Of course! In my opinion they are very nice and beneficial.
འདུ་ཤེས། = perception; འདུ་བ། = to collect, assemble; ཤེས་པ། = to know, to cognize, as in: ཡེ་ཤེས། =primordial wisdom ཤེས་རབ། = insight; བཞི། = four, as in: ནམ་དུས་བཞི། = the four seasons
Yesterday, my Dharma friend said that when going to receive a Dharma talk, it’s very important to give rise to a good motivation. (H)
བཀའ། = speech (H), as in: བཀའ་དང་བསྟན་བཅོས། = the word of the Buddha and the commentaries, བཀའ་མོལ་གནང་བ། = to have a conversation (H); ཆོས། = Dharma, as in: ཧིན་དྷུའི་ཆོས་ལུགས། = Hinduism
the fault, flaw of not listening well, carefully
Among the Three Flaws that are described in the Buddhist texts, the first one is not listening well, right? (H)

ཡག་པོ། = good, well; མ། = not = དགག་སྒྲ།, as in: སེམས་ཅན་མ་ལུས་པ། = [all] sentient beings without exception; ཉན་པ། = to listen, as in: ཉན་ཐོས། = listeners, śrāvakas; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; སྐྱོན། = flaw, fault
His uncle is a wonderful human being. He has only a few flaws and a whole lot of (good) qualities.
the fault, flaw of not keeping the meaning in mind
Since I have the second flaw of not being able to keep the meaning in mind, I usually take notes at the Dharma talks.

དོན། = meaning, purpose, as in: གཞན་དོན་སྒྲུབ་པ། = to accomplish the benefit of others; དག = plural marker; བློ། = mind, as in: བློ་བཟང་། = kind minded; ལ། = ལ་དོན།; མ། = དགག་སྒྲ།, as in: མ་རིག་པ། = ignorance; འཛིན་པ། = to hold, grasp, as in: བདག་འཛིན། = self grasping, འཛིན་གྲྭ། = class, བསྟན་འཛིན། = holder of the teaching; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; སྐྱོན། = flaw, fault
the fault, flaw of listening with a negative mindset, bad motivation
Sometimes it’s probably a bit hard to identify the third flaw, the flaw of listening with a negative mindset.

བསམ་པ། = thought, intent, as in: བསམ་བློ་གཏོང་བ། = to reflect, think; ངན་པ། = bad, negative, as in: ངན་སོང་གསུམ། = the three lower destinies; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; སྒོ་ནས། = in terms of, as in: སྒོ། = door, མཛད་སྒོ། = ceremony; ཉན་པ། = to listen, as in: ཉན་ཐོས། = listeners, śrāvakas; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; སྐྱོན། = flaw, fault
the fault of not listening (lit. not directing one's ears), like [a cup] turned upside down
If one explains the three faults using an example, the first one says: “the fault of not directing one’s ears, like a cup turned upside down”. (h)

རྣ་བ། = ear, as in: རྣ་རྒྱན། = ear ring; མི། = “not”, དགག་སྒྲ།, as in: མི་རྟག་པ། = impermanence; གཏད་པ། = to direct, to focus, as in: གསར་གཏོད་མཛད་པ། = to found, to establish; ཁ། = mouth, as in: ཁ་ལག = food; སྦུབ། = a vessel upside down; ལྟ་བུ། = like, as in: ཁོང་ཁྲོ་ལྟ་བུའི་སྡིག་པ་མེད། = “There is no evil like anger”; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; སྐྱོན། = fault, flaw
What is written in the Heart Sūtra? “There are no eyes, no nose, no ears, etc.” It explains about selflessness in a profound way. (H)
If we express the term “an upside down vessel” in ordinary language, it refers to a bowl placed upside down.
the fault of not remembering (lit. not keeping it in mind), like [a cup] with a hole in the bottom
Since I don’t have a good memory, in my opinion, the fault of not being able to keep things in mind like a vessel with a hole, seems the hardest to give up among the three flaws.

ཡིད། = mind, as in: ཡིད་ཆེས། = trust; ལ། = ལ་དོན།; མི། = “not”, དགག་སྒྲ།, as in: མི་གཙང་བ། = impure; འཛིན་པ། = to hold, grasp, as in: བདག་འཛིན། = self grasping, འཛིན་གྲྭ། = class and classroom, བསྟན་འཛིན། = holder of the teaching; ཞབས། = foot (H), as in: ཞབས་བྲོ་འཁྲབ་པ། = to dance, ཞབས་སྐོར། = kora (H); རྡོལ། = to come out, burst; ལྟ་བུ། = like, as in: ཁོང་ཁྲོ་ལྟ་བུའི་སྡིག་པ་མེད། = “There is no evil like anger”; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; སྐྱོན། = fault, flaw
What does the term “hole in the bottom” refer to? It means a cup that has a hole.
ཞབས། = bottom, also honorific of foot, leg; རྡོལ་བ། = to burst, to come out, to open
the fault of listening whilst having disturbing emotions, like [a cup] containing poison
The third flaw to be abandoned is the fault of listening while having disturbing emotions, like [a cup] contains poison.

ཉོན་མོངས། = disturbing emotions, as in: ཤེས་སྒྲིབ་དང་ཉོན་སྒྲིབ། = the cognitive and afflictive obscurations; དང་། = དང་སྒྲ།; འདྲེས་པ། = to mix, mingle; དུག = poison, as in: དུག་གསུམ། = the Three Poisons, དུག་སྦྲང་། = mosquito; ཅན། = having, as in: སེམས་ཅན། = animal; ལྟ་བུ། = like, as in: ཁོང་ཁྲོ་ལྟ་བུའི་སྡིག་པ་མེད། = “There is no evil like anger”; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; སྐྱོན། = fault, flaw
afflictions, disturbing emotions, afflictive emotions, kleśas
In the Buddhist scriptures it says that there are 84,000 afflictions, right?
The three, attachment, anger and ignorance are also called the “Three Poisons” because these afflictions are dangerous like poison.
the perception of oneself as a sick person, a patient
Even if one’s body is healthy, if you can give rise to a perception of yourself as being a patient while listening to the Dharma, it is beneficial.

རང་། = oneself, as in: རང་སྦྱོང་། = home work; ཉིད། = emphasiser, as in: སྟོང་པ་ཉིད། = emptiness; ལ། = ལ་དོན།; ནད་པ། = sick person, as in: ནད་ན་ཚ། = disease; ལྟ་བུ། = like, as in: ཁོང་ཁྲོ་ལྟ་བུའི་སྡིག་པ་མེད། = “There is no evil like anger”; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; འདུ་ཤེས། = perception, འདུ་བ། = to gather, collect, as in: ཚོགས་འདུ། = meeting; ཤེས་པ། = to know, as in: ཡེ་ཤེས། = primordial wisdom, ཤེས་རབ། = insight
perception, conception, notion, apprehension, idea, ideation
Everyone has their own perception. So it’s probably very important to be flexible and respectful because everything is merely one’s own way of perceiving things).
འདུ། = to include, multiply; ཤེས་ as in ཤེས་རབ། = insight, མངོན་ཤེས། = clairvoyance
the perception of the Dharma to be practiced as medicine
Giving rise to the perception of the Dharma to be practiced as medicine is easy for me because the Dharma really helps soothe suffering like medicine.

ཉམས་པ། = to degenerate, as in: ཉམས་མྱོང་། = experience, ཉམས་ལེན་བྱེད་པ། = to practice; བླང་བ། = to adopt, take up, as in: བླང་དོར་གྱི་གནས། = what is to be adopted and abandoned; གི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; ཆོས། = Dharma, as in: ཡི་ཤུའི་ཆོས་ལུགས། = Christianity; སྨན། = medicine, as in: སྨན་ཁང་། = hospital; ལྟ་བུའི་འདུ་ཤེས། = perception like...
the perception of practicing the Dharma as the process of recovery from illness
The perception of practicing the Dharma as the process of recovery from illness is really logical because if one does not practice, there is no way out of suffering.

རང་། = oneself, as in: རང་སྦྱོང་། = home work; གིས། = བྱེད་སྒྲ།; ཆོས། = Dharma, as in: ཧིན་དྷུའི་ཆོས། = Hinduism; ལག་ལེན་བསྟར་བ། = to practice, to apply; ལག་པ། = hand; ལེན་པ། = to take, as in: ཁས་ལེན་པ། = to accept; འདི། = this; ལ། = ལ་དོན; ནད། = disease, as in: ནད་ན་ཚ། = sickness; གསོ་བ། = to restore, repair, as in: ངལ་གསོ་རྒྱག་པ། = to take rest; ལྟ་བུའི་འདུ་ཤེས། = perception like before
sickness, disease of the outer body, sick person, patient
According to me, it’s probably harder to cure the inner diseases and sufferings of the heart or mind than most outer sicknesses of the body and being a sick person.

ཕྱི། = outward, outer, outside, as in: ཕྱི་རྒྱལ། = abroad, foreign country, ཕྱི་ལོགས། = outside; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; ལུས། = body, as in: ལུས་རྩལ། = physical exercise, འཇའ་ལུས། = rainbow body; ན་ཚ། = disease, as in: ན་ཚ་འཕོག་པ། = to be struck by a disease; དང་། = དང་སྒྲ།; ནད་པ། = sick person, as in: སྙིང་ནད། = heart disease
In Buddhism, the term “the three, body, speech and mind” is used a lot.
the disturbing emotions which cause the mind to be agitated, not in a state of peace
My grandmother says that the worst enemy in her life is not a person or animal but the disturbing emotions that cause the mind to be agitated. (H)

མ། = “not”, དགག་སྒྲ།, as in: སེམས་ཅན་མ་ལུས་པ། = [all] sentient beings without exception; ཞི་བ། = peace, as in: ཞི་བདེ། = peace and well being; བྱེད་མཁན། = agent, the one who does the action; གྱི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; ཉོན་མོངས། = disturbing emotions, as in: ཤེས་སྒྲིབ་དང་། ཉོན་སྒྲིབ། = cognitive and afflictive obscuration
It is written in the Thirty-Seven Practices of a Bodhisattva that attachment increases when we are with our families and friends. (H)
འདོད་ཆགས། = attachment/desire as in: འདོད་པ། = to wish, to want, འདོད་རྒྱལ། = ‘king of one's wishes’ (a Tibetan word category); ཆགས་པ། = to become
The verse from the patience chapter in the Bodhisattvacaryāvatāra that says that “there is no evil like anger” seems very important.
ཞེ། = inclination of the mind, སྡང་། = hate, hostility
According to Buddhism, animals have strong ignorance. I don’t agree with that perception.
At the end of the Dharma talk, རིན་པོ་ཆེ། said that it will probably be great if we are able to investigate whether we have those three flaws that he mentioned earlier. (h) (H)

གོང་། = above, as in: གོང་ས་མཆོག = His Holiness; དུ། = ལ་དོན།; ཞུས་པ། = to say, take (h), as in: ཞབས་ཞུ་བ། = waiter, servant; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; སྐྱོན། = fault, flaw; གསུམ་པོ། = the three, as in: དཀོན་མཆོག་གསུམ། = The Three Jewels
to give up, to abandon, to discard (ཐ་དད་པ།)
In Buddhism they talk about giving up the afflictions all the time. But, in my opinion, it is also important to abandon our bad habits, such as smoking, etc. (H)
to embrace, to take up, to rely upon, to serve, to go and see (a doctor or lama) (ཐ་དད་པ།)
If one wants to practice the secret Vajrayāna, it is of utmost importance to rely on the རྩ་བའི་བླ་མ།.
If one wants to do interpreting work, it will be of great benefit if one is able to keep in mind the most famous and often used quotations.
བློ། = mind, as in: བློ་བཟང་། = kind minded; ལ། = ལ་དོན།; འཛིན་པ། = to hold, grasp, as in: བདག་འཛིན། = self grasping, འཛིན་གྲྭ། = class, བསྟན་འཛིན། = holder of the teaching
We will all try our best to keep in mind the advice which our lama gave us yesterday. Those are indeed applicable. (H)
ཡིད། = mind, as in: ཡིད་ཆེས། = trust; ལ། = ལ་དོན།; འཛིན་པ། = to hold, grasp, as in: བདག་འཛིན། = self grasping, འཛིན་གྲྭ། = class and classroom, བསྟན་འཛིན། = holder of the teaching
to mix, to merge, to intermingle, mixture (ཐ་མི་དད་པ།)
When we speak mixing two languages, for example, Tibetan and English, we call that “neither goat nor sheep”.
to remember, recall, miss, memory, mindfulness (ཐ་མི་དད་པ།)
What is written in The Letter to a Friend? The Protector Nāgārjuna writes: “Mindfulness is the foundation of all good qualities.” (H)
as in: དྲན་གསོ་བྱེད་པ། = to remind somebody
If, after giving up the ten non virtues, one is even able to practice the ten virtues, it is very good. For example, after having given up taking lives, protecting lives (instead).
ཉམས་པ། = to decline, to degenerate; སུ། = ལ་དོན།; བླང་བ། = to pick up, to take up, as in བླང་དོར་གྱི་གནས། = what is to be adopted and abandoned
to practice, to put into practice, to apply (ཐ་དད་པ།)
According to the opinion of many lamas and learned ones, putting the conduct of non-violence into practice is of utmost importance. (H)
ལག་པ། = hand; ལེན་པ། = to take, as in: ཁས་ལེན་པ། = to accept
recover from a disease, heal a disease
What does one have to rely upon to recover from a disease? One has to rely on medicine, this is why it’s called the science of healing.
ནད། = disease, as in: ནད་ན་ཚ། = sickness; གསོ་བ། = to restore, repair, as in: ངལ་གསོ་རྒྱག་པ། = to take rest
to cause to be agitated, unpeaceful, anxious (ཐ་དད་པ།)
It’s not other people that causes one’s mind and life to be agitated and not peaceful. Most likely, it is one’s afflictions and other unwholesome thoughts.
མ། = not, དགག་སྒྲ།, as in: སེམས་ཅན་མ་ལུས་པ། = [all] sentient beings without exception; ཞི་བ། = peace, as in: ཞི་བདེ། = peace and well being; བྱེད་པ། = verbalizer, to do
to make sure to remember, to make sure not to forget, to try one’s best to keep in mind (ཐ་དད་པ།)
Since the verse which you told me today was beautiful, I’ll try my best not to forget it. (H)
མ། = དགག་སྒྲ།, as in: མ་རིག་པ། = ignorance; བརྗེད་པ། = to forget, as in: དྲན་པ་བརྗེད་པ།; བྱེད་པ། = to do
Since it is a waste of time to listen to the Dharma with a negative motivation, one should cultivate a wholesome mindset.
as in ངན་སོང་གསུམ། = the three lower realms
There are two types of snakes, the venomous ones and the ones without venompoison, right?
དུག = poison, ཅན། = having, as in སེམས་ཅན། = having mind, animal
What is the opposite of “outer”? It’s “inner” (or Buddhist). Therefore one divides the “insiders” and the “outsiders”.
as in ཕྱི་རྒྱལ། = foreign country, abroad
together with an example, illustrated by an example
Since many explanations in Buddhism are illustrated by an example, they are easy to understand and beautiful.
དཔེ། = example, as in: གཏམ་དཔེ། = proverb; དང་། = དང་སྒྲ།; སྦྱར་བ། = to join, as in: སྦྱོར་ལམ། = the Path of Joining; ནས། = འབྱུང་ཁུངས། particle
in terms of, with respect to, regarding
His Holiness says that in terms of charity, Christianity is very good. (H)
The verse from the Bodhisattvacaryāvatāra “there is no hardship like patience” is the first verse in the Patience Chapter.
How should this meaning be understood, interpreted, thought of?
I asked དགེ་བཤེས་མ་ལགས། how the meaning of the term “unity of clarity and emptiness” should be understood. (H) (h)

དོན། = meaning, purpose, as in: གཞན་དོན་སྒྲུབ་པ། = to accomplish the benefit of others; དག = plural marker; ག་རེ། = what; ལ། = ལ་དོན།; གོ་བ། = to hear, to understand, as in: ཧ་གོ་བ། = to understand; དགོས། = must, to have to, as in: དགོས་པ། = need, purpose
in brief, to summarize, in short
If one were to summarize today’s teachings, it might be that after giving up the three flaws, one has to give rise to the four perceptions.
མདོར། = in short, མདོ། = མདོ་སྡེ། = sūtra; ན། = ལ་དོན། = if
The term “those” is only used in Classical Tibetan, it is not used in Central Tibetan dialect.
དེ། = དེ་སྒྲ།; དག = pluralizer/plural marker in literary Tibetan
In future Dharma talks, I’ll do my best to try to listen in terms of having the Four Perceptions.
དང་། = དང་སྒྲ།; ལྡན། = to have, to be endowed with, as in: དགའ་ལྡན། = Tuṣita, བཅོམ་ལྡན་འདས། = The Transcendent Conqueror; སྒོ་ནས། = in terms of, as in: སྒོ། = door
What are the objects to whom Buddhists go for refuge? They are the Three Jewels.
ཡུལ། = object, place, as in: འབྲུག་ཡུལ། = Bhutan, བལ་ཡུལ། = Nepal, དམིགས་ཡུལ། = aim, objective
Their landlord is a wonderful human being. He has a lot of excellent qualities, such as patience, open mindedness, etc.
ཡོན་ཏན། = good qualities, as in: ཡོན་ཏན་མཛོད། = The Treasury of Precious Qualitie
When they enter a temple hall and see the statues of the Buddha, etc. faith and devotion naturally arises in some people. (H)
དང་བ། = lucid, clear, as in: དང་བའི་དད་པ། = lucid faith; དང་། = དང་སྒྲ་; མོས་པ། = admiration, devotion, as in: རེ་མོས་བྱེད་པ། = to alternate
Since our རིན་པོ་ཆེ། offered the refuge ceremony last Saturday at our Dharma center, a whole lot of folks came. (H)
སྐྱབས། = refuge, as in: སྐྱབས་ཡུལ། = objects of refuge; འགྲོ། = to go, as in: སྔོན་འགྲོ། = preliminaries
According to you, what do you think is the main and most powerful refuge among the Three Jewels? The Buddha, the Dharma or the Sangha?
as in: སྐྱབས་འགྲོ། = going for refuge, taking refuge
In my Dharma-friend’s opinion, among the many ways of protecting somebody from the fears and terrors of saṃsāra, the most beneficial one is to meditate on impermanence.
འཇིགས་པ། = fear, frightened, as in: འཇིགས་མེད་གླིང་པ།;སྐྲག་པ། = to be terrified, afraid
In the Buddhist scriptures they describe the suffering of saṃsāra beautifully by using the example of an ocean. (H)
སྡུག་བསྔལ། = suffering, སྡུག = སྡུག་པོ། = bad, poor, བསྔལ། = pain
I think that if one meditates a bit on the excellent qualities of the objects of refuge before becoming a Buddhist, the refuge will become genuine.
སྐྱབས། = refuge, see above; ཡུལ། = object, country, as in: བལ་ཡུལ། = Nepal, འབྲུག་ཡུལ། = Bhutan, དམིགས་ཡུལ། = objective, aim
the Three Jewels; the Triple Gem; the Three Rare and Sublime Ones
No matter how much her knees hurt, my grandma prostrates three times to each of the Three Jewels in the morning after getting up. (H)
དཀོན། = དཀོན་པོ། = rare; མཆོག = supreme, as in: མཆོག་ཏུ་གྱུར། = highest, གོང་ས་མཆོག = His Holiness; གསུམ། = three, as in: དད་པ་གསུམ། = the Three [types of] Fait
Since many causes and conditions need to be present to become an interpreter, one probably has to make a great effort.
རྒྱུ། = cause, as in: ལས་རྒྱུ་འབྲས། = karma, cause and effect; རྐྱེན། = condition, as in: མཐུན་རྐྱེན། = facilities, འགལ་རྐྱེན། = unfavorable condition
Among the four thoughts which turn the mind towards the Dharma, the first is about the suffering and flaws of saṃsāra, right?
འཁོར་བ། = saṃsāra, as in: འཁོར་ལོ། = wheel, དུས་འཁོར་དབང་ཆེན། = Kālacakra initiation; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; སྡུག་བསྔལ། = suffering, སྡུག = སྡུག་པོ། = bad, poor, བསྔལ། = pain
Yesterday, our བླ་མ། said that though faith is important in general, one needs to be careful about blind faith. (H)
as in: དང་བའི་དད་པ། = clear, lucid faith, འདོད་པའི་དད་པ། = longing faith
Before listening to the Dharma talk today, I had no idea that there are three or four kinds of faith. (h)
རིགས། = kind, class, as in: མི་རིགས། = human race, སྐད་རིགས། =language
In my opinion, clear faith is probably something that not only Buddhists, but other religions also strongly possess, right?
དང་བ། = clear, lucid; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; དད་པ། = faith, devotion
After cultivating yearning faith in her heart, she talks about nothing else but the three year retreat.
འདོད་པ། = to wish, to want, as in: འདོད་ཆགས། = attachment, སྙིང་འདོད་པ། = to really want; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; དད་པ། = faith, devotion
I wonder what trusting faith is like. - Good question! I have zero clue. I still have a lot of doubts.
ཡིད་ཆེས། = trust, as in: ཡིད་ཆེས་བྱེད་པ། = to trust, to believe in; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; དད་པ། = faith, devotion
The venerable one says that among the Four Types of Faith, the hardest one to cultivate is irreversible faith. (H)
ཕྱིར། = again, back, behind; མི། = དགག་སྒྲ།; ལྡོག་པ། = to reverse; དད་པ། = faith
manner of going for refuge, taking refuge
Because རིན་པོ་ཆེ། explained about the manner of going for refuge before offering the actual refuge ceremony, it was beneficial for us. (H)
སྐྱབས། = refuge; ལ། = ལ་དོན།; འགྲོ། = to go, as in: སྔོན་འགྲོ། = preliminaries; སྟངས། = nominalizer, way of doing x, as in: གནས་སྟངས། = situation, འཚོ་བ་སྐྱེལ་སྟངས། = life style
the teacher of the path to liberation [the Buddha]
If one is a Buddhist, one considers the Buddha, the Transcendent Conqueror as the main teacher on the path of liberation, right?

ཐར་པ། = liberation as in: ཚེ་ཐར་གཏོང་བ། = to save lives by buying animals who are to be killed; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; ལམ། = path, as in: ལམ་ཀ = road, path, ལམ་ལྔ། = the Fivefold path, ཚོགས་ལམ། = Path of Accumulation, སྦྱོར་ལམ། = Path of Joining; སྟོན་པ། = to show, to teach, as in: བསྟན་འཛིན། = holder of the teaching; པོ། = བདག་སྒྲ། – makes it into a person
Since accomplishing the path of liberation takes many years and years and lives after lives, sometimes I get a bit discouraged.
What is the name of the movie about Venerable ཆོས་འཕེལ།? It’s called “Angry Monk”.
དགེ་འདུན། = the Sangha; དགེ་བ། = virtue, as in: དགེ་རྒན། = teacher; འདུན་པ། = aspiration, zeal, as in: སྨོན་འདུན། = wish, desire, hope
the companion on the path to liberation
I really consider the kind Dharma friends who practice with us as companions on the path to liberation.

ཐར་པའི་ལམ། = path of liberation; སྒྲུབ་པ། = to accomplish, as in: ཚིག་སྒྲུབ། = sentence; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; གྲོགས། = friend, companion, as in: གྲོགས་མོ། = female friend, འཛིན་གྲོགས། = classmate, ཆོས་གྲོགས། = Dharma friend
Before taking refuge, it’s probably very important to know what the precepts are. If one cannot accept them, it might be best not to take refuge.
བསླབ་པ། = to train, to teach, as in: སློབ་གྲྭ། = school, སློབ་ཕྲུག = student; བྱ། = which one must do; བྱ་བ། = action, as in: བྱ་ཚིག = verb
supports and representations (i.e. of the Buddha)
At their monastery, there are a lot of representations of the body, speech and mind of the Buddha, [namely] statues, religious texts, and stūpas.
as in: འཇིག་རྟེན། = world; མཆོད་རྟེན། = stūpa
Her auntie says that she prays and does a lot of circumambulations for the sake of all sentient beings when visiting sacred places. (H)
སེམས་ཅན། = sentient beings, animals; སེམས། = mind, heart, as in: སེམས་ཙམ་པ། = Percetption Only, སེམས་པ་བཟང་པོ། = kind-hearted; ཅན། = having, as in: དབྱངས་ཅན།
His Holiness the Dalai Lama says that if we are unable to accomplish much benefit for others, we at least need to try our very best to stop harming them. (H)
གནོད་པ། = harm, as in: གནོད་སེམས། = harmful mind; འཚེ་བ། = violence, harm, as in: སྤྱོད་པ་འཚེ་བ་མེད་པ། = conduct of non violence
people who have negative motivation and conduct
The mother tells her son that if he spends time with people who have a negative mindset and bad conduct, it will have a bad influence [on him]. (H)

མི། = person, as in: མི་སྐྱ། = lay person; བསམ། = thought, as in: བསམ་ཚུལ།= opinion; སྤྱོད། = conduct, as in: གསང་སྤྱོད། = toilet; བེད་སྤྱོད་གཏོང་བ། = to use, to make use of; སྤྱོད་འཇུག = Entering the Way of a Bodhisattva; ངན་པ། = bad, negative, as in: ངན་སོང་གསུམ། = the three unfortunate destinies, the three lower realms
What is the essence of Buddhism? It is the view on dependent arising and the conduct of non-violence, right?
ཉི་མ་ལགས། says that when she first saw the poor people who live in the streets in India, strong compassion arose in her heart.
as in: སྐྱེས་སྐར། = birthday, སྐྱེ་བ་སྔ་ཕྱི། = past and future lives
Since doing “life liberation [practice]” allows one to protect fish and other animals that are to be killed from death, I like this practice a lot.
ལས། = འབྱུང་ཁུངས་; སྐྱོབས། = refuge, as in: སྲུང་སྐྱོབ་བྱེད་པ། = to protect
In the context of the guru yoga practice of the Secret Mantrayāna, the Vajrayāna it is indispensable to cultivate a hundred-percent faith in the བླ་མ།.
དད་པ། = faith, as in: འདོད་པའི་དད་པ། = longing faith; བསྐྱེད་པ། = to give rise to, as in: སྐྱེད་རིམ། = development, generation stage
If one is an ordinary being, accomplishing the path takes a long time. If it’s མི་ལ་རས་པ།, that’s a different story.
According to my observations, generally in Asia, a lot of young people have respect towards elderly people. (h)
གུས། = respect, veneration; ཞབས། = foot, leg (H), as in: སྨན་ཞབས། = nurse; ཞུ་བ། = to say, take (h), as in: ཞབས་ཞུ་བ། = waiter
to socialize, to befriend, to make friends with, to associate oneself with
Since her daughter socializes with kids who have good conduct, her behavior and way of talking is slowly becoming more gentle.
དང་། = དང་སྒྲ།; འགྲོག་པ། = to socialize, as in: གྲོགས་པོ། = friend, འཛིན་གྲོགས། = classmate; རྒྱུ་ཡོད་མ་རེད། = one should not
What is the opposite of exalted? It is probably the terms “ordinary” and “common”.
ཁྱད་པར། = difference, as in: ཁྱད་མཚར་པོ། = strange; ཅན། = having, as in: སེམས་ཅན། = animal, sentient being
same as above, same as before
If one doesn’t wish to explain the same [thing] over and over again, it’s very handy to just say: “Same as above”, right? (h)
གོང་། = above, as in: གོང་ས་མཆོག = His Holiness; དང་། = དང་སྒྲ།; གཅིག་པ། = same, as in: གཅིག = one, གཅིག་པུ། = alone
Since she is a modest and genuine practitioner, I consider her advice very precious.
ཡང་དག་པ། = completely pure, ཡང་། = again, also, as in: ཡང་འཇུག = second suffix, དག་པ། = pure, as in: མ་དག་པ། = impure, not purified
If there are many different ethnicities, religions and languages in that town, I want to move to that place.
མི། = དགག་སྒྲ།; འདྲ་བ། = to be alike/similar, as in: འདྲ་པོ། = similar, སྐུ་འདྲ། = statue
The word and meaning are really in line when we call the practice one does before the main practice the “preliminary practice”.
དངོས། = real, actual as in: དངོས་གནས། = really, actually, དངོས་པོ། = entity, thing
So, to be completely honest, I probably won’t be able to go to Mount Kailash with you all because I’m afraid to get altitude sickness. (H)
དངོས། = real, actual, as in: དངོས་པོ། = thing, entity; གནས། = to abide, as in: གནས་སྟངས། = situation, གནས་མཇལ། = to do pilgrimage; དྲང་གནས། = honestly, as in: དྲང་པོ། = honest, དྲང་བདེན། = honesty
The explanation that you gave yesterday in class was really logical and applicable.
བློ། =mind, as in: བློ་བཟང་། = kind minded; ལ། = ལ་དོན།; འབབ་པ། = to fall, as in: ཆར་པ་འབབ་པ། = rainfall, འབབ་ཆུ། = waterfall
I take refuge, go for refuge (can also mean “Oh my gosh!”)
According to the Tibetan way of speech, upon seeing a dire situation, many people would say: “སྐྱབས་སུ་མཆི།”
སྐྱབས། = refuge, as in: སྐྱབས་འགྲོ། = going for refuge, taking refuge; སུ། = ལ་དོན།; མཆི། = to go, to come
I wonder what [they] mean [when they say this]
During the Dharma talk, the བླ་མ། spoke about Buddha Nature. I wonder what that means. (H)
འདི། = this; འི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; དོན་དག = meaning, as in: གཞན་དོན་སྒྲུབ་པ། = to accomplish the benefit, purpose of others; དག = plural marker; ག་རེ། = what; ཡིན་ན། = I wonder
in order for it to become
In order for your Tibetan to become fluent, you need to speak as much as you can.
ཡོང་བ། = to come, as in: ཡོང་འབབ། = income; ཡག = nominalizer; གི། = འབྲེལ་སྒྲ།; ཆེད་དུ། = for, in order to
if one subdivides faith [into its different kinds]
རིན་པོ་ཆེ། says that if one subdivides faith, there are four types of faith to be identified. (H)
དད་པ། = faith, as in: དང་བའི་དད་པ། = clear, lucid faith; ལ། = ལ་དོན།;དབྱེ། = division, as in: དབྱེ་བ་ཕྱེ་པ། = classified, subdivided; ན། = ལ་དོན།
so, in the end, at last, now, finally
Our professor said: “So, in the end, we will all recite the long life prayer together!”
ད། = ད་ལྟ། = now, as in: དུས་ད་ལྟ་བ། = present time, tense; མཐའ་མ། = in the end, as in: གྲུབ་མཐའ། = philosophical tenet, མཐའ་ལ་མ་ལྷུང་བ། = not falling into an extreme; ལ། = ལ་དོན།
if one summarizes, to express in brief
So, if one summarizes today’s Dharma teaching, it is most important to give rise to a good motivation in one’s heart and be altruistic.
མདོར། = in brief, as in: མདོ་སྡེ། = sutra; བསྡུས་པ། = to be condensed, as in: སྙིང་བསྡུས། = summary; ན། = ལ་དོན།
heartfelt, from the core of one’s heart, from the bottom of one’s heart
Since you guide me skillfully, I say to you from the bottom of my heart: “Thank you very much, it is so kind”. (h)
སྙིང་། = heart, as in: སྙིང་རྗེ། = compassion, སྙིང་ནད། = heart disease; ཐག་པ། = bottom; ནས། = འབྱུང་ཁུངས།
The father advised the teenager not to socialize with people who have bad behaviors and don’t respect others. (H)
འགྲོག་པ། = to socialize, as in: གྲོགས་པོ། = friend, འཛིན་གྲོགས། = classmate; རྒྱུ་ཡོད་མ་རེད། = one should not
